I want to be clear, I am not defending Rice here, but I think before this 
video was released there was some possibility that Rice wasn't quite the 
monster he obviously is.

Based on what we knew prior to Monday: 
1) Rice and Palmer were both charged with domestic violence.
2) There was no meaningful prosecution or suspension from the NFL.
3)  Before they enter the elevator you can see her take a little swing at 
him, which also makes you think she was also an active aggressor.
4)  We see Rice dragging Palmer's unconscious body around like a sack of 
potatoes.

I don't think it was insane for me to think maybe based on all the 
circumstances that maybe she was an active participant and was pushed and 
smashed her head or Rice hit her in "self defense".  I honestly thought 
when we saw the video we were going to see her attack him and lose a fight. 
 Obviously, still ethically/morally wrong, but I figured a safe guess based 
on the charges being plead down and mild NFL punishment.  Again I want to 
be clear that even in that, now hypothetical, circumstance Rice is 
undoubtedly wrong.  You bear hug her or you cover up and take a few lumps 
and then leave her ass, you don't hit her with a full force left cross.

Just my two cents as someone who wasn't rabid for his banishment for life 
or for Goodell to be fired upon first hearing about and seeing the original 
video.  Having seen the whole video now, the NFL and Ravens made changes to 
get this right, Rice will likely never play another down in the league.﻿

IT'S TIME TO GROW UP.

The gender size/strength discrepancy is an effective way of derailing the 
issue at hand. " You never put your hands on a woman". "Just walk away". 
These are things we here all the time and it's basically saying to men and 
boys that because of these general physical attributes that we are born 
into that we are not allowed to defend ourselves. The right to self defence 
is and has always been a HUMAN right.  

This is where the next counterpoint comes into play: "We don't want to give 
men a free pass to hit women". I agree. It's an option that should never be 
taken lightly but when you have a two people that supposedly have the same 
rights but one is held to higher standard of responsibility then we a 
recipe for disaster.

Women are the ones who are held to a lower standard of responsibility than 
men especially in cases of domestic violence. Like that cliche view that 
you wouldn't hit someone with glasses. As if the object itself removes any 
sense of accountability that the wearer may have and on face value it is 
really quite ludicrous. When it comes to girls and women, their smaller 
size and strength is often used as a way to minimise the degree of 
responsibility they may have in an altercation. A shield in the form of 
infantilization that can in effect give them a 'free pass' to assault men 
and in all fairness and equality should never be aloud to happen.

I respect women too much to exempt them from responsibility and I need to 
say this to any who may be reading this:

You are no better than me. You are not special and you are not exempt from 
the consequences of your ACTIONS. Everything we do can have a direct effect 
on others and the big thing about being a mature adult is to recognise and 
learn from our mistakes. 

We all need to reminded of that so that next time we even consider being 
violent, we just walk away. If not? We deal with the fallout like big girls 
and boys.

IT'S TIME TO GROW UP.  ﻿

"Situational couple violence (SCV),also called common couple violence 
(CCV), is not connected to general control behavior, but arises in a single 
argument where one or both partners physically lash out at the other. This 
is the most common form of intimate partner violence, particularly in the 
western world and among young couples, and involves members of both sexes 
nearly equally."

just assuming that because she becomes unconscious, he must have punched 
her?

she passed out, or because of the supposed punch?

using his foot as she is lying in the doorway, implying that he is trying 
to hurt her. Clearly at this point is is just trying to get her out of the 
elevator. Try handling a limp body yourself and you may find that trying to 
use your foot as support is completely reasonable. You seem to assume 
malice everywhere.

tried to get her out of the elevator. However, it is the correct procedure 
to put an unconscious person on the side, with bent hip and knees! When you 
say that he seems not to care, what are you basing that on? It seems like

helped to whole heartedly appreciate that this is not how you handle your

kind of dismissive rhetoric in suggesting that "He'll never change", or

won't help this individual acclimate back into the society that he is a

Psychological help he apparently and desperately needs. But to consider him

These videos are so frustrating. Even if it's obvious that the guy was in 
the wrong and committed some kind of assault, the total refusal to ever put 
any blame on the woman in this situation is ludicrous (and anyone that does 
so is apparently "victim blaming" and thus their opinion is dismissed). She 
hit him. No, he didn't have to hit her back. It's assault but we don't know 
his INTENTIONS, and this is really important. Perhaps it was an instinctual 
reaction, in which case you don't even have much control over the force 
with which you strike back, you just swing. You're not gonna be thinking 
"OK I just got hit, I'm gonna hit back but I don't wanna do TOO much damage 
so I'll only put in 50% power", come on. On the other hand, perhaps he does 
this a lot and knew he was hitting her hard. At the same time we don't know 
her intentions. Was this a one-off thing, or does she do this a lot? If you 
hit your partner regularly and they DON'T ever hit back, that's domestic 
abuse. If you hit your partner regularly and they always hit back...well 
that's a pretty weird relationship.

Obviously the lack of punishment initially and the disparity between drug 
offences and violent offences are both stupid and need to be addressed. The 
guy's lack of reaction after knocking her out is also very troubling and 
further implicates him in this case. But PLEASE can we be SENSIBLE about 
these situations instead of just repeating the idiotic "men shouldn't hit 
women EVER" and "violence is NEVER the answer" ideologies. The latter in 
particular is all well and good when looking at a situation from a distance 
but when you're in the heat of the moment, these things sometimes happen. 
Hitting back is sometimes the best answer to ensure your well-being, 
although obviously not in this specific case. As far as we know, she 
initiated violence. Did she deserve to get knocked out? No. Did she deserve 
to face some consequence for that action? It'd be difficult to say no.

Just...ugh, some rationality please. Also, couples, stop hitting each other 
god damn it.﻿

I'm personally against domestic violence but I also get called a sexist for 
my own reasons for that view. I have a serious question though. Is physical 
aggression just the one thing that "gender equality" doesn't have to do 
with? I don't think a man should hit a woman in any way because (in my 
opinion) it's hardly ever going to be a fair fight. You can call me sexist 
or whatever you want but that is also the only reasoning I can see against 
domestic violence (other than the very reasonable argument that all 
violence is bad).

The only thing is if you want to define the factors that lead to most mixed 
gender fights being unfair you would have to list the differences between 
women and men, in capability and in the general population. That's 
definitely not what the gender equality movement (as far as I can tell) 
wants. I know like most other reasonable people that men and women are 
crazy different. I also know it's stupid to say that either one is better 
than the other, that's like saying oranges are better than apples. Just 
like apples and oranges, I think it's stupid to say that men and women are 
equal across the board. (Rights shouldn't have anything to do with any 
classification of person) 

So again how does the fight against domestic violence line up with the 
gender equality movement? If we are all completely equal then why would one 
party in a fight be the only one charged with a crime? If we are all 
completely equal why would gender even come into question during the case?

I have a personal vendetta against domestic violence and I don't want 
anyone to think I'm trying to excuse it. Thing is I read feminist shit all 
day all over the internet and there are several subjects that I sincerely 
agree with them on, but after enough well written articles and carefully 
formed (one sided) arguments I start to sympathize with the movement in 
general. I can't stand hardcore feminists but there is substance to gender 
equality and I feel myself wanting to speak out on some of the issues. Then 
something like this happens and every seemingly smart person that's made 
good points in the past about equality (like Ana or Cenk) is just outraged 
because someone won a fight. If you take gender out of it it looks like 
this: #1 strikes #2, #2 pushes #1, #1 strikes back, #2 strikes #1, #1 
charges at #2, #2 strikes #1, #1 is unconscious. If we're being completely 
unbiased #1 (Rice's fiance) began the altercation. 

If you disagree with me please don't be mean about it, but I'd like to know 
why. Real quick I'm saying that domestic violence is horrible criminal 
behavior. I'm saying that the feminist movement (the one the general public 
sees and the one represented by people like Ana) is spreading an ideology, 
that I believe, supports the idea that gender shouldn't matter in any 
context. I'm saying I can't agree with that because of things like this. ﻿

Firstly, you can't tell from that video how he's feeling. I *highly* doubt 
he feels indifferent, and people react differently. For all you know, he 
was freaking out and didn't know what to do. It probably took a few seconds 
for him to return to a rational state of mind and do something about the 
situation. Secondly, she hit him first. For goodness sakes, you can't just 
give her a free pass on instigating violence just because she's a woman; 
you're treating her like a child, not an equal person.

lastly, we don't know the nature of their relationship. For all we know, 
*she* could be an abusive wife, and this could be one of many times she 
lashed out at him, and maybe he finally decided he wasn't gonna take it 
anymore, snapped and released all of that repressed passive-aggressive 
anger with one punch. Or maybe it was just a one-off fight between them, or 
he could well be a wife-beater. You *don't know*, and you're being 
incredibly irresponsible by making these baseless assumptions.

this footage came out and the media descended on them, and now it's ruining 
their lives. Ah, but let me guess - she's just a little child with no mind 
of her own, and you all know what's best for her. You in your profession as 
journalists can psychoanalyze her based on one video that lacks any 
context. God, this right here is why I dislike the media so much. People 
are just pawns in a political game to you.

would be 100% on your side. But the way you just casually admonish her 
unprovoked assault, and demonize his retaliation, is absurd. Instigating 
violence is wrong regardless of your gender - retaliation is

+Clarence LeBlanc You might want to look at all the versions of Assault and

http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/assault

ASSAULT, crim. law. An assault is any unlawful attempt or offer with force 
or violence to do a corporal hurt to another, whether from malice or 
wantonness; for example, by striking at him *or even holding up the fist at 
him in a threatening or insulting manner*, or with other circumstances as 
denote at the time. an intention, coupled with a present ability, of actual 
violence against his person, as by pointing a weapon at him when he is 
within reach of it. 6 Rogers Rec: 9. When the injury is actually inflicted, 
it amounts to a battery. (q.v.) 
     2. Assaults are either simple or aggravated. 1. A simple assault is 
one Where there is no intention to do any other injury. This is punished at 
common law by fine and imprisonment. 2. An aggravated assault is one that 
has in addition to the bare intention to commit it, another object which is 
also criminal; for example, if a man should fire a pistol at another and 
miss him, the former would be guilty of an assault with intent to murder; 
so an assault with intent to rob a man, or with intent to spoil his 
clothes, and the like, are aggravated assaults, and they are more severely 
punished than simple assaults.
